Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: CISE-CCF-AF-Algebra: DMS-Algebra: Computational Differential Algebra

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Partial differential algebraic equations (PDAEs) have many important applications, such as those in cellular biology, chemistry, mathematical physics, mechanics and dynamical systems, control theory, differential geometry, and analysis. Algorithms on PDAEs have been instrumental in simplifying and solving practical problems but are increasingly taxed as the size of problems increases. Improvements in efficiency will reduce the time for scientists to find properties, and perhaps solutions, to the systems they are working on.

The research consists of developing a computational theory for systems of PDAEs, including those with parameters, and to design algorithms that provide efficient descriptions of their solutions. For non-parameterized systems, the PI will first obtain complexity estimates for existing differential elimination algorithms. For systems with parameters, he will study the structure of their differential Galois groups, which are linear groups consisting of solutions to PDAEs themselves, via representation theory. Better understanding of them can then be applied to improve the efficiency of existing algorithms or create new ones.

Despite over a century of numerous studies on PDAEs, as pioneered by Holder, Janet, Riquer, Ritt, Kolchin, and recently furthered by Singer, Boulier, and Hubert, among many others, there do not yet exist methods computationally efficient enough to explore and understand the differential algebraic behavior of solutions of these systems. As a result of the proposed research activities, new improved complexity upper bounds will highlight some bottlenecks of existing algorithms, allowing deeper exploration of designs for more efficient algorithms. The research activities will further develop the theory of radical differential ideals which is essential for any substantial progress in theoretical and algorithmic developments. Among the open problems this project will investigate is the Ritt Problem, which if solved, would provide unique, irredundant, and effective representations of radical differential ideals.

Institution.Name: CUNY Queens College
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported the development of theory and algorithms for polynomial differential and difference equations. The educational component of the project consisted of training and mentoring junior researchers, course development at the graduate and undergraduate levels, and engagement of high school students into research.

 

Scientists use polynomial differential and difference equations to model a variety of natural phenomena. This award supported research that resulted in theory and algorithms to simplify and analyze such equations, making them easier and quicker to solve and thus providing a better understanding of the processes they model in practice. The approach that was taken belongs to the area of symbolic computation and is crucial in the problems in which exact answers are strongly preferred to numerical estimates. Symbolic algorithms typically require a substantial amount of computational resources. To address this, the new theory that was developed in this award resulted in new and more efficient algorithms and in new complexity estimates of existing algorithms for the above problems. Pre-print versions of research articles supported by this award are available for free public use.

 

This award provided support to seven Ph.D. students in the form of mentorship, research assistantship, and travel support. Four of these students have defended their dissertations and are pursuing their academic careers. The award supported a postdoc, who currently holds a tenure-track academic position. A high school student was involved in the research, presented the results at the Long Island Science and Engineering Fair and won third place there.

 

Five research and training workshops and a conference with a training component were supported by this award. These events featured research presentations by senior researchers, practice job-talk presentations by junior participants, and one-on-one career advising meetings, in which junior participants were paired with senior participants. Three of these workshops featured panel discussions on topics essential for junior researchers' career development. The award also supported two research seminars and a special session at a conference, in the subject of the award. Presentations at these events have been video recorded and are available for free public use.

 

As a part of the award, undergraduate-level and graduate-level courses were developed and taught. Detailed lecture notes for these courses are available online for free public use.

 


Last Modified: 06/15/2017
Modified by: Alexey Ovchinnikov
